title: How to Measure an Arm Hole

steps.headline: Extend one arm straight out from your body.
steps.description: Raise your arm and hold it parallel to the floor. Either arm is fine, though it will be easiest to do your measuring with your dominant arm and use your non-dominant arm for reference. If possible, ask someone to lend you a hand. That way, they can maneuver the measuring tape while you focus on holding your arm in position and checking the resulting measurements. You always want to start with your arm away from your body rather than down at your side in order to ensure that the finished garment is comfortable and form-fitting.

steps.headline: Align the end of a soft measuring tape with the center of your shoulder.
steps.description: Place the “0” mark against the bony part of your shoulder joint, right where your arm meets your torso. This will serve as the starting point for your measurement. Use the pad of your thumb or forefinger to pin the end of the tape in place. A soft measuring tape, which you can flex, bend, and twist with ease, is better suited for taking accurate body measurements than a rigid tape measure or ruler. The spot where you begin your measurement will correspond to the area where the garment’s neck and shoulder seams intersect.

steps.headline: Draw the tape down the front of your shoulder and under your armpit.
steps.description: It should run in a straight, vertical line from the top of your arm to the bottom where it begins to curve under. Make sure that the tape is resting flat against your body in all places, with no wrinkles or twists. The vertical measurement of the front part of the arm is sometimes referred to as the arm hole “depth.” While the arm hole depth is an important dimension to know when making clothes from scratch, isn’t a complete arm hole measurement. Ordinarily when you order custom-fit clothing or have an item altered, the arm hole depth is the measurement the maker or tailor will ask for.

steps.headline: Continue wrapping the tape all the way around to your original starting point.
steps.description: Guide the tape up and over the rear of your shoulder, then back around to the top. Hold the two sections firmly in place and note the number at the point where they overlap. This is your full arm hole measurement. Your full arm hole measurement should be roughly twice your arm hole depth. The two numbers may not track exactly, however, so it’s best to take the full measurement rather than simply doubling the number you got for the depth.Tip: If you’re working alone, try bending your non-measuring arm at the elbow and using the tip of one finger to secure the starting end of the tape as you negotiate the loose end.

steps.headline: Move your arm around to make sure you have full range of motion.
steps.description: Without letting go of the measuring tape, work your arm up and down, side-to-side, and in wide circles. If the tape restricts your movement at any point, slide the two sections apart a small amount until it feels comfortable. If you have an assistant, have them slip two fingers between the measuring tape and your body to make sure that you’re leaving adequate room. Just be careful not to lose your grip on the tape as they do. When in doubt, it’s better to settle for a measurement that’s a little too big than one that’s a little too small.

methods.name: Estimating an Arm Hole Measurement from a Shirt

steps.headline: Find a shirt or top that fits you well.
steps.description: Go through your clothes and pick out a garment with sleeves  that are form-fitting yet comfy. This is usually a good sign that the arm holes are just the right size for you. It doesn’t matter how long the sleeves are—the shirt you choose could be a t-shirt, sweatshirt, blouse, dress shirt, or sweater. It could even be sleeveless, as long as it has stitched arm holes. This method can come in handy when you want to get a better idea of your ideal arm hole size but don’t feel confident in your ability to measure your own arm yourself and don’t have anyone around to help you.

steps.headline: Spread the shirt out face-up on a flat, stable surface.
steps.description: Take a moment to smooth out the fabric around the arm and shoulder area. Do your best to eliminate all wrinkling, folding, or bunching. Inconsistencies in the shape of the garment could throw off your measurements. For precision’s sake, it’s best to use a table, desk, countertop, or similar work surface with no give or changes in level.

steps.headline: Run a soft measuring tape along the front arm hole seam.
steps.description: Position the starting end of the tape measure at the top of the seam, where it intersects with the seam originating at the garment’s neckline. Then, carefully adjust the loose end of the tape so that it lies along the curve of the seam all the way to the armpit area. Turn the measuring tape over onto its side to create a natural curve that follows that of the seam. Otherwise, it will be prone to bending or creasing. Make sure the tape is resting on the body of the garment rather than the sleeve. Though the measurement should be the same either way, measuring from the body will create a small margin of error and guarantee that the arm hole of the new garment isn’t too tight.

steps.headline: Make a note of the seam’s length.
steps.description: Once you’ve got the measuring tape situated properly, look at the number aligned with the bottom of the seam and jot it down on a scrap sheet of paper. This measurement represents the garment’s arm hole depth, which is approximately one half of the full arm hole measurement. If you’re not too particular about the way your new shirt fits, you have the option of using the arm hole depth as your official arm hole measurement. Consider adding ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) to be absolutely sure that the arm holes on the finished garment will be big enough. For a more exact fit, you’ll want to confirm the length of the other side of the seam, as well.Alternative: Lay the tape flat and measure from the top of the seam straight down to the armpit section of the sleeve.

steps.headline: Turn the shirt over and measure the rear arm hole seam separately.
steps.description: Smooth out the fabric around the arm, just as you did when laying the shirt out for the first time. Then, repeat the measuring process, aligning the “0” end of the tape with the top of the seam and snaking it along the curve to the bottom edge. Record this measurement next to the first. In most cases, the arm hole seams at the front and back of the garment will be identical. However, the rear seam may occasionally be larger by as much as ⁄8 in (1.6 cm), so it’s best to take both measurements individually, just to be on the safe side.

steps.headline: Add the two measurements together to get your full arm hole measurement.
steps.description: All you have to do now is use basic math to find the sum of the pair of numbers you just wrote down. If the front seam was 7 ⁄4 cm (2.9 in) and the back seam was 7 ⁄2 in (19 cm), your final arm hole measurement would be 14 ⁄4 in (37 cm). Add up your fractions carefully. If you make a mistake, your new shirt may not have the perfect fitted look that you were going for. Keep in mind that the number you end up with will only be an estimate of your true arm hole measurement, and won’t be as accurate as more traditional measuring methods. Even so, it should still help you achieve a satisfactory fit when ordering or making tailored clothing.
